content.description: Varied and enjoyable climbing on a low-angle corner.  Climb up to and then around the tree, finishing up on the inside face.
content.protection: Small to medium.  Beginning has a move or two pulling over a large overlap before you can get in your first piece.
content.location: The leftmost, left-facing corner on A-frame wall. Shares a start with Mossad, but stays in the corner.

content.description: The arête to the left of A-Frame .
content.protection: Minimal small pro.  Trees at to top for TR anchors.

content.description: Note the light tan colored cavity/roof before stepping off the ground. Start up Badlands until your hands are level with good holds on the small slab between you and the tan cavity. Step left onto the slab and traverse your way into the light tan cavity, with hands above the roof. Pull the roof and head straight up the slab above, passing over a diagonal crack on the way. Finish to the right of a small (4”) wobbly hemlock at the edge of the cliff.
content.protection: Multiple small trees at the top for TR anchors with webbing or static. Maybe you can get a piece in at the large diagonal crack, or a nut just above the fixed copperhead, but there’s nothing I would want to fall on after that. Better off TR.
content.location: Scramble up the choss and broken branches to the base of an overgrown/mossy crack system to the left of the obvious A-Frame and the the right of the classic Mossad. This crack system is Badlands, and it shares a start with Star of David.

content.description: The start is pretty self explanatory.  This Pinnacle Classic at the left end of the main buttress starts up a small but awkward overlap.  Continue up to a larger overlap and up a nice face.  The crux would have to be moving out on to the face and setting your self up.
content.protection: Your better off top roping this climb...But if your up for it, the protection up to the tree is decent but the face is a run out due to a missing bolt.
content.location: The route is to the right of Wild and Wooly.  Wild and Wooly follows the overhanging left face corner system, passing a ledge with a tree.

content.description: Climb a few intricate moves through a set of roofs down low to gain the face above.  Very small moves throughout, but the difficulty eases considerably once the face is gained.

Climb the cracks between the large blocks on the low-angle slope.  The route trends right as you pass a left-facing corner formed by a protruding block.  A good choice for a first-time leader or young kids on top-rope. 

  Variation (5.7+) Climb straight up on the slabs, avoiding the cracks.
content.protection: Takes a lot of pro.  Trees at top for anchors
content.location: Between Emerald City Wall and A-Frame Wall.  Walk off left.

content.description: A rabbly crack with many stances and some bushwacking toward the top.
content.location: The obvious rabbly crack just left of A-frame.

content.description:
Climb A-Frame to a ledge. Climbs up the center of the overhanging face to the right of A-Frame. 

  Ken used two 'offset' Top Ropes to make the ascent and was called out in Climbing Magazine for being a Dinosaur for the style he choose to put up this route (ie double TRs rather than a bolt or two).
Climb the A shaped ramp and stem your way up the chimney to the pine tree. Take a left at the top of the climbers trail. The A shaped ramp is hard to miss.
content.protection: Small rack. Takes lots of pro.

content.description: This section has everthing from 5.4 to 5.11.  Classics such as Mossad which start out on an awkward overlap and finsh on a crimpy face climb.
